newsitem.title: FRANCE: BOXING-DOMINGUEZ RETAINS TITLE AGAINST CAUTIOUS TAFER.
newsitem.headline: BOXING-DOMINGUEZ RETAINS TITLE AGAINST CAUTIOUS TAFER.

text.p: Argentine Marcelo Dominguez drew on his immense staying power to retain his World Boxing Council cruiserweight crown in a unanimous points decision against Frenchman Akim Tafer on Saturday.
The judges awarded the fight to Dominguez, who knocked out Tafer two years ago for the vacant title, with scores of 115-114, 117-112, 117-115.

Tafer, failing for the third time in an attempt to win the crown, had a considerable height and reach advantage over the Argentine but failed to press home his advantage when he held the upper hand in the early rounds.
He appeared to lose heart as the fight wore on and became frustrated when he was unable to put down the tough Argentine, making his fifth consecutive defence.
Dominguez, who has little style and often looks ungainly but is renowned for his courage, stayed in the battle despite taking a near perfect Tafer uppercut in the seventh.
The 27-year-old Argentine was almost always the more ambitious of the fighters, looking constantly for ways beneath or round the Frenchman's defence.
Tafer, who turns 30 on August 27, was in tears after the decision, saying in the heat of the moment: "Tonight in my head that's the end, I quit boxing."
He added: "I'm going to rest for a fortnight or three weeks and I'll announce my decision. That was one of the hardest fights of my career.
"I had my chance but I didn't manage to take it. I suffered a sudden fatigue in the sixth and seventh rounds and it's then that I must have lost the fight.
"I finished stronger than him. I didn't think the verdict would be so severe. That's boxing. If the better man won, so be it."
